predicted_text:
When it comes to fall fashion trends, one item that never goes out of style is a trusty pair of jeans. Whether you're headed on a weekend getaway or a longer trip, jeans are a versatile wardrobe staple that can be worn all year round. 

The beauty of jeans lies in their ability to effortlessly complement any outfit. Pair them with a cozy oversized sweater and ankle boots for a casual yet chic look, or dress them up with a tailored blazer and heels for a more polished ensemble. With jeans, the possibilities are endless.

Not only do jeans offer endless styling options, but they also provide comfort and durability, making them perfect for travel. Whether you're exploring a new city or embarking on outdoor adventures, jeans are designed to withstand the wear and tear of any activity. 

Furthermore, jeans come in a variety of styles and cuts to suit every body type and personal preference. From classic skinny jeans to trendy wide-leg styles, there is a perfect fit for everyone. Additionally, denim comes in various washes and colors, allowing you to customize your look according to your individual style.

Jeans also offer the advantage of being low-maintenance. Unlike delicate fabrics that require special care, jeans can be easily thrown into a suitcase without worrying about wrinkles or damage. This makes them an ideal choice for travelers who value convenience and efficiency.

So, whether you're packing for a weekend getaway or a longer trip, make sure to include a trusty pair of jeans in your suitcase. Their timeless appeal and versatility make them a must-have item for any fashion-conscious traveler. Embrace the comfort, style, and endless possibilities that jeans bring, and you'll be ready to take on your fall adventures in style.

predicted_text: This paper focuses on the few-shot learning problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. FewJoint is a new few-shot learning benchmark for joint dialogue understanding, which provides a new corpus and a code platform to advance the research in this field. The authors find that insufficient performance in the few-shot setting leads to noisy sharing between the two sub-tasks and introduces a trust gating mechanism to block low-confidence intent information to ensure high-quality sharing. They also introduce a meta-learning strategy based on Reptile to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. The proposed method achieves new state-of-the-art performance on two datasets.

request.prompt:
Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.
Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.

predicted_text: This paper focuses on the few-shot learning problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. FewJoint is a new few-shot learning benchmark for joint dialogue understanding, which provides a new corpus and a code platform to advance the research in this field. The authors find that insufficient performance in the few-shot setting leads to noisy sharing between the two sub-tasks and introduces a trust gating mechanism to block low-confidence intent information to ensure high-quality sharing. They also introduce a meta-learning strategy based on Reptile to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. The proposed method achieves new state-of-the-art performance on two datasets.

request.prompt:
Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.
Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.
